Award.AwardTitle: Development, Implementation and Assessment of Novel Inquiry-based Interdisciplinary Materials on Sustainability for the Chemistry Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The challenges of sustainability span disciplines, and students prepared to address those challenges must be able to think critically across traditional content areas. In this project, faculty from the Chemistry Department and Sustainability Studies Program at Stony Brook University are collaboratively developing, implementing, and assessing learning materials for three undergraduate chemistry courses that focus on sustainability. The developed materials will address the chemistry of environmental processes, environmental degradation, energy production and the connections between chemistry-related and non-chemistry-related aspects of sustainability, such as economics and policy. Students will conduct meaningful research in the laboratory course by evaluating the effectiveness of solar-powered algal turf scrubbers to remove excess nitrogen and phosphorus nutrients from streams and coastal waters, as well as the suitability of using the resulting algal biomass as fertilizer. These represent potential abatement strategies for the coastal water quality problem of fertilizer run-off. Developed materials will employ inquiry based learning strategies using the POGIL model, and modern technology - simulation model exercises that guide students in understanding chemistry concepts and their connections to issues of sustainability will be created. Developed learning materials will be evaluated and disseminated through publications and presentations, and will be designed to be suitable for adoption at other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of population growth, increasing per capita consumption of resources, and continued reliance on fossil fuels, the human population faces unprecedented environmental, social, and economic challenges. Analyzing the complex challenges of sustainability and developing solutions to them will require expertise from many fields. Preparing students to evaluate the challenges of sustainability and to consider the potential contributions and limitations of their major field of study to address these challenges is an important task for educators. In this TUES project, an interdisciplinary team consisting of a chemist, a biologist, an environmental economist, and a regional planning and policy expert, developed, assessed, and revised learning materials for use in undergraduate chemistry courses about issues of sustainability. One set of activities is for use in an undergraduate non-science majors’ course, in which chemistry concepts are taught in the context of issues of sustainability (such as air pollution, stratospheric ozone depletion, the greenhouse effect and climate change, and energy sources). Many non-science majors find chemistry content more relevant and interesting when it is explicitly connected to issues that they care about.

The other set of activities is for use in an intermediate level undergraduate chemistry course. These activities focus on the chemistry of environmental processes, environmental degradation, energy production, and some connections between chemistry-related and non-chemistry-related aspects of sustainability. Some of the chemistry-related questions students consider in this course are: Why are chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) so damaging to the stratospheric ozone layer? Why are some greenhouse gases hundreds to thousands times more effective than carbon dioxide at retaining earth’s heat? What is the effect of an increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration on the oceans? How can chemists and engineers make molecules and materials in a more environmentally benign way? Some of the questions students consider in this course that make connections between chemistry-related and non-chemistry related aspects of sustainability are: How do economists think about environmental degradation? In addition to regulation, what approaches are there to reduce environmental degradation? How is the process of risk assessment done- what types of data are needed and what assumptions are made? How can issues that have both technical aspects and social implications be effectively communicated to the general public?

The materials developed are for use in a classroom and make use of a pedagogy in which a significant proportion of class time is dedicated to students working on the activities in small teams. In the activities, students explore new concepts, connect these new concepts to knowledge they already have, and apply the concepts to solve problems. There is also an emphasis on developing process skills, such as communication, information processing, team management, critical thinking, problem solving, and metacognition (thinking about and regulating one’s thinking process). Lectures by the instructor are short and targeted.

In this TUES project, we have also developed a project-based component for an environmental chemistry laboratory course. The project focuses on a strategy to mitigate the effects of eutrophication (the presence of excess nutrients) in coastal waters. Eutrophication has many potential adverse effects: toxic algal blooms, formation of hypoxic regions (aka “dead zones”), and harm to coastline-protecting salt marshes.
